questions.text: A 7-year-old girl who has a background of sickle cell disease presents with 3-day history of myalgia, fever and coryza. Over the last day, her mother has noticed a rash on her hands and feet. She is very lethargic and pale. Her Hb, WBC counts and platelets are low. What is causing this?
questions.solution:
Parvovirus-associated aplastic crisis is a condition caused by infection with Parvovirus B19, primarily affecting people with underlying red blood cell disorders, such as sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis, or other hemolytic anemias. This virus targets and infects erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, leading to a sudden halt in red blood cell production.

  • Parvovirus B19 infection are associated with aplastic crisis. Child presents with acute onset anemia and fever associated with rashes. CBC shows
  • Reticulocytosis and nucleated RBCs are seen in recovery phase.
  • Management is largely supportive.

Option A: Splenic sequestration presents with splenomegaly, hypovolemia and anemia.

Option B: Acute chest syndrome presents with fever, hypoxia and respiratory distress.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Parvovirus B19 infection are associated with aplastic crisis. Child presents with acute onset anemia and fever associated with rashes. CBC shows reticulocytopenia

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child has a swollen painful knee joint after falling down. His skin cuts bleed a lot and are difficult to control. What could be a probable coagulation profile?
questions.solution:
• Features are suggestive of a hemarthrosis which would be seen in a bleeding disorder like hemophilia which typically has an elevated aPTT.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Hemophilia is a genetic bleeding disorder where the blood does not clot properly, leading to excessive bleeding from even minor injuries. This condition is typically caused by a deficiency in certain clotting factors-most commonly Factor VIII in Hemophilia A and Factor IX in Hemophilia B. Because it is X-linked, hemophilia primarily affects males, while females can be carriers.

questions.text: A Child has sickle cell disease. He is at increased risk of developing infection with which of the following bacteria?
questions.solution:
Patients with sickle cell anemia are particularly susceptible to infections caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. This increased vulnerability is primarily due to the functional asplenia (or absence of spleen function) that often develops in these patients. The spleen typically plays a key role in filtering bacteria, especially encapsulated organisms like S. pneumoniae.

Other organisms to which sickle cell patients are more susceptible include:

  • Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Salmonella species(often linked to osteomyelitis in these patients)
  • Parvovirus B19(which can cause aplastic crisis)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Children with sickle cell are more susceptible to infection with encapsulated bacteria like salmonella, Pneumococcus, Meningococcus, E.coli etc. due to splenic atrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following results is expected in Hb electrophoresis of a child who is a sickle cell trait
questions.solution:
Predominance of Hemoglobin S (HbS): The majority of hemoglobin in the blood will be HbS, the abnormal form responsible for sickling.

Low or Absent Hemoglobin A (HbA): In sickle cell anemia (HbSS), HbA (normal adult hemoglobin) is absent since both hemoglobin genes produce HbS.

Hemoglobin F (HbF): Some patients may have a higher level of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which does not sickle and can reduce disease severity. HbF levels are particularly higher in infants and some adults with hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin.

Possible Hemoglobin A2 (HbA2): A small amount of HbA2 (typically less than 3.5%) may also be present.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Those affected (HbSS) have absent HbA, variable HbF and 75-95% HbS.

  • Carriers (HbA) have 60% HbA >50%, <2% HbF and <50% HbS on haemoglobin electrophoresis.

questions.text: A child comes with multiple petechiae in her lower limbs. A CBC is ordered which shows low platelet counts, rest all parameters are normal. Past history is significant for a URTI 8 days ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Immune (or idiopathic) thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is common in children. In most cases, a preceding viral infection can be documented. The platelet count frequently is less than 20,000/mm3, but other laboratory test results are normal, including the bone marrow aspiration(which may show an increase in megakaryocytes).
  • Treatment consists of observation or possibly intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), intravenous anti-D (in Rh-positive patients), immunosuppressives, or steroids.The history must be reviewed for other possible causes of thrombocytopenia, including recent MMR vaccination, drug ingestion, and human immunodeficiency virus.

Option B: TTP presents with pentad of Thrombocytopenia, anemia, neurological symptoms, renal impairment and fever.

Option C: HUS presents with thrombocytopenia, anemia and often has GI symptoms secondary to Shigella infection.

Option D: Dengue rashes are associated with high grade fever and also has hemoconcentration.

questions.text: Following image is seen in peripheral smear in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of Heinz body. It is most significantly seen in G6PD deficiency which is composed of denatured hemoglobin due to oxidative stress.

  • G6PD (Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase) deficiency is a genetic disorder affecting the enzyme G6PD, which plays a crucial role in protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage. It is an X-linked recessive condition, meaning it predominantly affects males, while females can be carriers.

Key Features of G6PD Deficiency

  1. Hemolytic Anemia: Triggered by oxidative stress from certain medications (like sulfa drugs, antimalarials), infections, or foods (notably fava beans). Oxidative stress leads to the destruction of red blood cells, causing hemolytic anemia.
  2. Symptoms During Hemolytic Episodes: Jaundice, dark urine, fatigue, pallor, and shortness of breath.
  3. Diagnosis: Blood tests measure G6PD enzyme activity. Testing is typically done when patients are not in an active hemolytic episode, as the test may be falsely normal during a crisis due to selective survival of enzyme-sufficient cells.
  • Option A : Sickle cell anemia can have similar appearing body called as Howell Jolly bodies, but the RBC are sickle shaped.
  • Option C and D :Such findings are absent in AML and elliptocytosis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: G6PD (Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase) deficiency is a genetic disorder affecting the enzyme G6PD, which plays a crucial role in protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage. It is an X-linked recessive condition, meaning it predominantly affects males, while females can be carriers.

questions.text: Which of the following is a not a cause of hemorrhagic anemia in a neonate?
questions.solution:
Diamond Blackfan syndrome is a congenital hypoplastic anemia and not hemorrhagic anemia.

Diamond-Blackfan Anemia (DBA) is a rare, inherited bone marrow disorder where the bone marrow fails to produce enough red blood cells, leading to severe anemia. It usually presents in infancy or early childhood and is associated with specific genetic mutations that affect ribosomal protein production, which is crucial for cell growth and function.

Causes of Neonatal hemorrhagic anemia are listed below:

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy who presents to you with lethargy and his urine has become dark in colour. There is no history of excessive exercise or beetroot consumption; he had a festive meal of chicken, fish, broad beans and rice for lunch. His examination is normal and he is afebrile. His examination is otherwise normal. What is the most likely underlying cause of his new symptoms?
questions.solution:
• In G6PD deficiency, acute hemolysis may be precipitated by infection, the most common precipitating factor. Certain drugs including nitrofurantoin, fava beans (broad beans)and naphthalene in mothballs can also precipitate hemolysis. The urine is dark as it contains hemoglobin as well as urobilinogen.

Option B: Sickle cell anemia usually have earlier presentation, with splenomegaly in most of the cases is apparent.

Option C: Thalassemia trait are usually asymptomatic with most common presentation being chronic anemia.

Option D: Pyelonephritis is a febrile illness with abdominal pain.

questions.text: A 2-year-old who has eczema has come for routine check-up. He is noticed to be having pallor. The remainder of his examination is normal. His mother reports that he has been eating bits of carpet from his room recently. Investigations reveal: Hb-6.6 mg/dL; WBC-10.2x109/L; platelet count: 350x109/L; MCV-60 fL (normal: 75-87 fL). What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
• Iron-deficiency anemia is the most likely diagnosis and iron therapy is indicated. The presence of 'pica' strongly suggests iron deficiency.
  • Iron deficiency anemia is a condition in which the body lacks enough iron to produce adequate hemoglobin, the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. This deficiency can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, pale skin, and shortness of breath. One peculiar symptom associated with iron deficiency anemia is pica, a craving for non-nutritive substances, such as ice, clay, dirt, or paper.
  • He may well be a picky eater and survives on cow's milk and little else. In some children anemia can be due to a β-thalassemia trait. The blood parameters should be repeated after a course of treatment and if there has not been a response he should be tested for β-thalassemia trait.

Option A: Dietary advice is required but iron therapy is a must as his anemia is severe.

Option B and D: Macrocytosis is usually seen in vitamin B12 deficiency and folic acid deficiency.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: One peculiar symptom associated with iron deficiency anemia is pica, a craving for non-nutritive substances, such as ice, clay, dirt, or paper.

questions.text: A 5 years old boy is troubled by recurrent nose bleeds, the last of which took 1.5 hours to stop. He has no other medical problems. His examination is normal except for pale conjunctivae. Investigation reveals: Hb- 8.6 gm/dL; WBC -10.2x109/L; Platelet count- 350x109/L; Prothrombin time- 16 seconds (control: 12-15 s); Activated partial thromboplastin time -46 seconds (control: 25-35 s); Fibrinogen: 2.5 g/L (normal: 2-4 g/L); Factor VIII: just below the normal range. What is the most likely cause of his bleeding?
questions.solution:
• On investigation, hemophilia A and von Willebrand disease (vWD) will both have a deranged activated partial thromboplastin time. However, in hemophilia A it is much more pronounced. The clinical features are also less pronounced in vWD, as in this child.

Von Willebrand Disease (VWD) is a common inherited bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (VWF), a protein that helps blood clot.

  • Cause: Genetic defect affecting von Willebrand factor, impacting blood clotting.
  • Types:
    • Type 1: Partial quantitative deficiency of VWF (most common and mildest).
    • Type 2: Qualitative defects in VWF (subtypes 2A, 2B, 2M, 2N).
    • Type 3: Near-total or complete absence of VWF (most severe and rare).
  • Symptoms:
    • Frequent nosebleeds
    • Easy bruising
    • Heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding
    • Prolonged bleeding after injuries or surgeries
  • Diagnosis: Blood tests measuring VWF levels, activity, and factor VIII levels.
  • Treatment:
    • Desmopressin (DDAVP): Helps release stored VWF in mild cases.
    • VWF concentrates: For severe cases or surgery.
    • Antifibrinolytic agents: Prevents breakdown of clots.

Option B: Spontaneous soft-tissue bleeding, such as large hematomas, does not occur in vWD. A family history is common.

Option D: ITP is ruled out as platelet counts are normal.

Option C: Vitamin K deficiency presents very early, mostly in neonatal or infancy.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: On investigation, hemophilia A and von Willebrand disease (vWD) will both have a deranged activated partial thromboplastin time. However, in hemophilia A it is much more pronounced. The clinical features are also less pronounced in vWD, as in this child.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to clinic with fatigue, pallor, and a recent history of easy bruising. She is afebrile. A complete blood count with differential reveals a neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated mean corpuscular volume, and her reticulocyte count is low. She is referred to a pediatric hematologist, and a diagnosis of severe aplastic anemia is confirmed, with a hemoglobin of 9.8 g/dL. What is the first-line therapy for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• An allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the first-line therapy for a patient with severe or very severe aplastic anemia if a human leukocyte antigen-matched sibling donor can be identified. A cause should be identified if possible.
  • Pancytopenia is seen on a complete blood count of a person with aplastic anemia, associated with a low reticulocyte count. A bone marrow biopsy is performed to confirm the diagnosis, which also demonstrates low cellularity of all three cell lines. Severity of disease is based on bone marrow cellularity, absolute neutrophil count, platelet count, and absolute reticulocyte counts.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplantation (SCT) is a treatment option for severe aplastic anemia (SAA), a life-threatening condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells. In SAA, an allogeneic SCT involves replacing the patient's diseased bone marrow with healthy stem cells from a donor.

questions.text: You are counseling a father about the treatment options for his child with β-thalassemia major. In addition to the increased risk of infection, splenectomized patients are at an increased risk of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Splenomegaly can be a complication of chronic transfusions, which is the mainstay of treatment for thalassemia major.
  • Chronic transfusions can decrease extramedullary hematopoiesis and prolong and improve quality of life. However, patients who develop splenomegaly have an increased transfusion requirement due to the associated hypersplenism and increased RBC clearance. As a result, splenectomy can be recommended.
  • It is well known that asplenic patients are at higher risk of infection from encapsulated organisms, and should be immunized prior to splenectomy. However, these patients are also at higher risk for thrombosis and pulmonary hypertension.

Incorrect Options: There is no known association between splenectomy and renal failure, malignancy, aplastic anemia, or increased bleeding.

choices.text: Enhanced release of iron from macrophages

questions.text: Patient with juvenile rheumatoid arthritis hemoglobin of 10.5 g/dL. Iron studies show normal transferrin saturation and an elevated ferritin. You suspect anemia of chronic disease. Which of the following is likely to have contributed to his anemia?
questions.solution:
• Anemia of chronic disease is multifactorial and likely due to impaired iron mobilization and decreased intestinal absorption of iron.
  • Cause: Chronic inflammation leads to reduced iron availability, impaired erythropoiesis (red blood cell production), and decreased red blood cell lifespan.
  • Mechanism: Inflammatory cytokines (e.g., IL-6) increase hepcidin production, which traps iron in cells and limits its availability for red blood cell production.
  • As in this vignette, the anemia is usually mild to moderate, normocytic, and normochromic. Serum iron levels are low, but transferrin saturation is normal and serum ferritin is typically elevated due to the inflammatory state. Additionally, in anemia of chronic inflammation, production of hepcidin, a peptide hormone synthesized by the liver, is increased.
  • Hepcidin acts as a negative regulator of iron release by acting to decrease ferroportin expression.

Option A and C: As ferroportin is required for both intestinal transport of iron and macrophage release of iron, the decrease in ferroportin leads to decreased iron absorption and decreased release of iron from macrophage stores.

Option D: Humans do not have a mechanism of active iron excretion.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Anemia of Chronic Disease (ACD), also known as Anemia of Inflammation, is a type of anemia commonly seen in chronic infections, autoimmune diseases, cancer, and chronic kidney disease.

Blood Tests: Show low hemoglobin, normal or low iron, high ferritin (indicating stored iron), and normal to low transferrin saturation.

questions.text: A newborn female develops jaundice at 12 hours of life. Her indirect bilirubin is 21.2 mg/dL. His mother's blood type is AB+; her blood type is A+. Her direct Coombs test is negative. Her CBC shows WBC 15,200/cumm, Hb 10 g/dL, Hct 30%, MCV 98 fL, MCHC 37 g/dL, Platelets 2.75 lac/cumm. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
• The patient has hereditary spherocytosis, which can be confirmed by osmotic fragility testing.
  • Osmotic Fragility Test: Spherocytes are more susceptible to lysis in hypotonic solutions. This test measures how easily red blood cells burst when placed in increasingly diluted saline solutions.
  • This patient's jaundice is not consistent with physiologic jaundice given the elevated bilirubin level within the first 24 hours of life. In this setting, with an MCHC of greater than 36 g/dL, the most likely diagnosis is hereditary spherocytosis in the newborn period.Outside the newborn period this typically presents as intermittent jaundice and palpable splenomegaly.

Option A: Neonates with G6PD deficiency can also present with non-physiologic jaundice; however, G6PD deficiency is X-linked and this patient is a female. In addition, the MCHC is normal in patients with G6PD.

Option B: Hemoglobin Electrophoresis is a laboratory technique used to separate and identify different types of hemoglobin in the blood. This test is essential for diagnosing hemoglobin disorders such as sickle cell disease, thalassemias, and hemoglobin variants.

Option C: Reduced UGT1A1 activity leads to elevated bilirubin levels, potentially causing jaundice.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited red blood cell disorder characterized by the presence of spherical-shaped red blood cells (spherocytes) due to defects in the proteins that maintain cell membrane stability. This condition leads to hemolytic anemia as the spleen destroys the abnormal spherocytes more readily than normal red blood cells.

choices.text: Annual neurologic assessments during well-child checks

questions.text: Evaluation of a 9-year-old girl with known SCD reveals right-sided weakness and slurring of speech without any associated pain. Her vital signs are within normal limits for her age. Which of the following screening tests might have helped to prevent this complication of SCD?
questions.solution:
• Transcranial Doppler ultrasound should initially be performed at 2 years of age. If normal, it should be repeated annually until the patient is 16 years old.
  • TCD identifies children with sickle cell anemia who are at high risk for ischemic stroke by detecting elevated blood flow velocities in the cerebral arteries, indicating narrowing or increased resistance.
  • If two ultrasounds are abnormal, transfusion therapy typically is initiated and continued indefinitely to help prevent stroke.

Option A and B: CT and MRI without any signs of stroke are not indicated. A change in hemoglobin level does not indicate potential stroke in a patient with SCD, but may be concerning for infection or aplastic crisis.

Option D: Although neurological examinations are an important part of any physical examination, changes in the examination would indicate an already evolving process, rather than help to predict the potential for future disease.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Regular TCD screening is a crucial component of stroke prevention in children with sickle cell anemia, allowing for early identification and intervention to reduce the risk of serious neurological complications.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is seen by a pediatrician for constipation and was noted to look pale. Haematological testing reveals that he is anemic with Hb of 10 g/dL (both MCV and MCHC are low). He is given a course of iron therapy but his anemia does not improve. Further testing reveals 5% hemoglobin A2 (HbA2) and 3% fetal hemoglobin (HbF). What is the most likely pathology?
questions.solution:
Beta Thalassemia is a genetic blood disorder caused by mutations in the HBB gene, resulting in reduced or absent production of the beta globin chains in hemoglobin.

Key Points on Beta Thalassemia:

  1. Types:
    • Thalassemia Minor (Trait): One defective gene; usually asymptomatic or mild anemia.
    • Thalassemia Intermedia: Moderate anemia; may require occasional transfusions.
    • Thalassemia Major (Cooley's Anemia): Two defective genes; severe anemia requiring regular blood transfusions and medical management.
  2. Symptoms:
    • Fatigue, weakness, and pallor.
    • Bone deformities due to bone marrow expansion.
    • Growth delays and jaundice in severe cases.
  3. Diagnosis:
    • Blood Tests: Show low hemoglobin, microcytosis, and hypochromia.
    • Hemoglobin Electrophoresis: Identifies decreased HbA and increased HbF and HbA2 levels.
  4. Treatment:
    • Thalassemia Major: Requires regular blood transfusions and iron chelation therapy to prevent iron overload.
    • Bone Marrow Transplant: Potential cure, primarily for severe cases.
  • βThalassemia trait typically presents with anemia only, that does not respond to iron therapy. Ferritin levels done before starting iron therapy could have reveled elevated ferritin, while iron deficiency anemia has decreased ferritin.
  • Elevated HbA2 is seen in thalassemia.

Option A: Sickle cell anemia shows HbS in Hb Electrophoresis.

Option C: Megaloblastic anemia would have high MCV.

Option D: Iron deficiency anemia responds to iron replacement therapy, which is an earlier marker.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Beta Thalassemia is a genetic blood disorder caused by mutations in the HBB gene, resulting in reduced or absent production of the beta globin chains in hemoglobin.

choices.text: Parallel rays of tubular structure in lysosomes

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was found to have hepatosplenomegaly and delayed milestones. The liver biopsy and bone marrow biopsy revealed PAS positive histiocytes. Electron microscope finding of these histiocytes will most likely be
questions.solution:
• Hepatosplenomegaly with PAS positive histiocytes suggests diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH)
  • The hallmark of LCH is clonal proliferation of monocyte lineage.
  • The presence of birbeck granulesin the cytoplasm of tumor cells is characteristic of LCH. Birbeck granules are tennis racket shaped bilaminar granules. They are not seen in all tumor cells by electron microscopy, hence detection of S-100 and CD1a by immunohistochemistry are needed for confirmation of diagnosis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The presence of birbeck granules in the cytoplasm of tumor cells is characteristic of LCH.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-year-old son with Down syndrome to the clinic because his gums have been bleeding for 2 weeks. She reports that he has been less energetic than usual. Examination reveals that the child has an oral temperature of 100°F, pallor, splenomegaly, gingival bleeding, and bruises on the lower extremities. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
• A high susceptibility to leukemia is associated with certain heritable diseases (Klinefelter syndrome, Bloom syndrome, Fanconi syndrome, ataxia telangiectasia, neurofibromatosis) and chromosomal disorders such as Down syndrome.
  • Children with Down syndrome have a 10- to 15-fold increased risk for developing leukemia and should have routine screening performed at well-child checks. Siblings of an acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) patient have a two- to fourfold increased risk for ALL, and the monozygotic twin of a child who develops ALL in the first year of life has a more than 70% chance of also developing ALL.
  • A few cases of ALL are associated with p53 gene aberrations. Overall, these genetic links account for a small number of total ALL cases.

Option A: Aplastic anemia can have similar symptoms but hepatosplenomegaly is absent.

Option B: ITP lacks systemic symptoms like fatigue and organomegaly, they primarily have bleeding manifestations.

Option D: Megaloblastic anemia presents with symptoms of anemia and neurological manifestation out of B12 deficiency. There is no systemic involvement.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: A high susceptibility to leukemia is associated with certain heritable diseases (Klinefelter syndrome, Bloom syndrome, Fanconi syndrome, ataxia telangiectasia, neurofibromatosis) and chromosomal disorders such as Down syndrome

questions.text: A child has been diagnosed with Diamond Blackfan syndrome. He is at increased risk of all the following cancers except
questions.solution:
• Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA) is a rare, inherited bone marrow failure disorder that primarily affects the production of red blood cells.
  • It's a congenital condition
  • The risk is increased for
    • Myelodysplastic syndrome
    • Acute myeloid leukemia
    • Colon carcinoma
    • Osteogenic sarcoma
    • Female genital cancers.

questions.text: Which of the following viral infection increases risk of developing lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)-associated lymphoma is a type of lymphoid malignancy linked to EBV infection, a virus that primarily targets B cells. EBV can contribute to lymphomagenesis by promoting cell proliferation, survival, and evading immune responses. EBV-associated lymphomas occur more frequently in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV, organ transplant recipients, or elderly patients

Types of EBV-Associated Lymphomas

  • Burkitt Lymphoma (BL): Often seen in endemic areas (such as in African populations), and predominantly affecting children, Burkitt lymphoma presents as a highly aggressive B-cell lymphoma with a characteristic "starry-sky" appearance on histology.
  • Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL): Specifically the mixed cellularity and lymphocyte-depleted subtypes are commonly associated with EBV. EBV infection contributes to the Reed-Sternberg cell formation seen in HL.
  • Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL): Particularly prevalent in immunocompromised hosts, EBV-positive DLBCL is an aggressive lymphoma that may present extranodally.
  • Primary CNS Lymphoma: Strongly linked with EBV in immunocompromised patients, especially in the context of HIV/AIDS. It typically presents with neurological symptoms.
  • Peripheral T-Cell and NK/T-Cell Lymphomas: In particular, NK/T-cell lymphoma, nasal type, has a strong association with EBV and is more common in East Asia and Latin America.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Latent EBV Infection: EBV establishes a latent infection in B cells, expressing latency genes (like LMP1, LMP2) that help evade immune detection and promote cell proliferation. Latency patterns vary across lymphoma types and influence their aggressiveness.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has ALL. His white cell count at diagnosis was < 50 x 10^9. He was also told that he was CNS negative and had some testicular leukaemia. He has shown good response to treatment so far. Which of these factors is high risk and means there is a poor prognosis?
questions.solution: KEY TAKEAWAYS: Poor prognostic features in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) are clinical, biological, and genetic factors that indicate a higher likelihood of treatment resistance or relapse.

questions.text: A 4 year old boy is found to be having a large abdominal mass on routine examination. What is the next most common differential for malignant etiology in this child after nephroblastoma?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of renal mass in a preschool child is Nephroblastoma. Other renal causes of an abdominal mass include polycystic kidney disease and hydronephrosis.
  • The most common malignant differential diagnosis of an abdominal mass in a preschool child is neuroblastoma, which may also present with hypertension, abdominal pain or fever.
  • Neuroblastoma is associated with periorbital ecchymosis (dark circles under the eyes), an abdominal mass which crosses the midline, and signs of bone marrow infiltration.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Most common cause of renal mass in a preschool child is Nephroblastoma.

questions.text: Which is the most common organ for metastasis in a child with Wilm's tumor?
questions.solution:
Wilms tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common malignant renal tumor in children. It primarily affects children between the ages of 1 and 5 years and arises from primitive kidney cells.

Wilms tumor results from abnormalities in genes responsible for kidney and genitourinary development. Key genetic abnormalities include:

  • WT1 and WT2 gene mutations on chromosome 11p, important in kidney development.
  • WAGR Syndrome: WT1 gene deletion leads to Wilms tumor, Aniridia, Genitourinary abnormalities, and Intellectual disabilities (Retardation).
  • Denys-Drash Syndrome: WT1 mutation is associated with Wilms tumor, gonadal dysgenesis, and nephropathy.
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome: WT2 gene abnormality associated with Wilms tumor, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, and organomegaly

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Wilms tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common malignant renal tumor in children.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a first line of investigation in a child suspected to be having Acute Myeloid Leukemia?
questions.solution:
• Bone marrow examination (including aspirate and trephine biopsy) is a definitive investigation to diagnose AML but would not be safe, tolerated or efficient as a first line investigation.
  • The most important initial investigations are a full blood count and blood film. If both are within normal range, acute leukaemia can be ruled out with a relative degree of certainty. Typically, the full blood count will demonstrate pancytopenia (due to bone marrow infiltration by blasts). Although the patient is likely to be neutropenic, many circulating blasts tend to dramatically elevate the overall white cell count, with blasts clearly visible on blood film.
  • In some cases, the white cell count may be only slightly raised and, if blasts remain sequestered within the bone marrow, it may even be lower than normal. Clearly identifiable blasts are not always present on a film. In these cases, the only clue that there is a serious underlying problem may be a few atypical cells in the blood film or the presence of leukoerythroblastic features.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Bone marrow examination (including aspirate and trephine biopsy) is a definitive investigation to diagnose AML.

questions.text: Which of the following is most common pulmonary tumor in children?
questions.solution:
The most common tumor types are

  • Carcinoid
  • inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor
  • pleuropulmonary blastoma

Rare pediatric lung tumors include

  • small cell carcinoma
  • adenocarcinoma
  • pulmonary capillary hemangiomatosis

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The most common pulmonary tumor in children is carcinoid tumor.
